projectDesc.p: The Greenfield Digital Project interprets the story of Bankers Trust Company, a large Philadelphia bank that failed in 1930, through a selection of primary source documents, contextual essays, and teacher resources. The project is part of a larger effort funded by the Albert M. Greenfield Foundation to make HSP's 20th-century holdings more accessible.

list.item: DR. C. E. BEURY, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD

p.orgName: BANK OF PHILADELPHIA AND TRUST COMPANY

div.p: I am attaching copies of letters which have gone out to our depositors, as these letters best explain the step that has been taken, as of this date, by unanimous vote of your Board of Directors.Lewis and Samuel Barker sent a letter on this date to depositors of both banks announcing the consolidation. Lewis also sent a personal letter to "depositors and customers" explaining why he thought the consolidation made sense.

To those of our stockholders who are not acquainted with the strength and favorable position of Bankers Trust Company, I would add that Bankers Trust Company has Capital, Surplus and Undivided Profits of approximately $7,500,000. This consolidation makes the deposits $50,000,000., and will bring the number of depositors to 138,000. We will be among the first ten banks in Philadelphia. Two offices of Bankers Trust Company will be discontinued and other economies will be possible, with resultant advantage to stockholders.

Your officers and directors feel that the terms of consolidation will prove equitable for our stockholders and are in their best interest. When the figures are worked out, our stockholders will have the opportunity of exchanging the net worth of their stockholdings in Bank of Philadelphia for stock in Bankers Trust Company on the basis of the the then book value of the latter. Our interests are all with the consolidated institution. Our stockholders should follow the lead of their directors and give the consolidation unanimous support. More than that, we should endeavor to build into this great financial institution which is resulting from the consolidation, all the good will and value that can come from our earnest support. Bankers Trust Company of Philadelphia is splendidly equipped to handle every phase of modern banking business.

I trust stockholders will particularly make it a point to call at our offices, which you will find even more attractive under this enlarged management, and strengthen by word and by action the good will which we desire this consolidation to carry. You will find enclosed a formal notice of the meeting of stockholders which is called for August 12th, but will be adjourned to and held on August 18th, to formally approve of the agreement of consolidation. Holders of a majority of the stock have already signified such approval. If you do not intend to be personally present, please return the enclosed proxy promptly.
